newsitem.title: USA: Ill. gov and lawmakers meet Thur on school funding.
newsitem.headline: Ill. gov and lawmakers meet Thur on school funding.

text.p: Illinois Gov. Jim Edgar and legislative leaders are scheduled to meet Thursday afternoon for their first formal talks on the governor's proposed school funding reform package.
Edgar has proposed a 25 percent state income tax increase to provide $1.2 billion of property tax cuts and $600 million for public schools.

The proposal would increase the state income tax from 3 percent to 3.75 percent to generate about $1.5 billion of additional revenues. The stated goals of property tax cuts and school funding leave the proposal with a $340 million hole.
A special committee of eight legislators and aides to the governor prepared the plan and began unveiling it to lawmakers on Wednesday.

Edgar, Republican state Senate President James "Pate" Philip and Democratic House Speaker Michael Madigan plan to meet in the governor's office at 2:30 p.m. CDT. The minority leaders in the house and senate have also been invited as have the members of the legislative committee.
A question high on everyone's list to answer is should the governor and legislative leaders fill the gap before presenting a formal plan to the General Assembly, Madigan's spokesman Steve Brown said.
The plan prepared serves as a "blue print" or model and all the leaders will have questions and concerns about it, said Patty Schuh, spokeswoman for Philip.
Philip would be reluctant to approve a significant increase in the income tax, but is open to discussion, Schuh said.
